11th November During the afternoon a radio was sent that, as a death had occurred on H.M.A.T. Ascanius, ensigns would be lowered to half mast. At three p.m. flags were lowered & the Ascanius dropped out of line & the soldier was buried with military honours. In ten minutes

the Ascanius was steaming back to her position. It cast a gloom over all, so solemn a service. That evening beautiful cool breezes sprang up & eased the trying heat. To add to the comfort as it were, the military bands on several of the transports could be heard very softly in the distance. It is remarkable to notice the difference bright music makes in the soldiers. There was no swishing of water owing to the calm sea & it brightened the men up to hear such pieces as the "Soldiers Chorus" from Faust. After the band had played God save the King they all turned in.
Entry.39:
About three a.m. I met O’Reilly who was on picket duty, & we sat on the rail & had a long chat. He was very fond of his sister & asked me to forward some photos to her. He then took me down to see his own horse & the way he treated her was a credit to him. Man that he was he thought the world of her & when he went up to her, & called her by name, although asleep, she pricked up her ears & rubbed her nose on his shoulder. Poor creatures, cramped together in the terrible heat, each with nostrils widely extended & breathing heavily, they were a 

patient, devoted lot. When it was time to awaken the relieving picket he said Let him have another hour’s sleep, so we sat on the rail & he talked about his home life until it was time to wake the relief. I then took up my watch for an hour or two, and as there was "nothing doing" I went out for some fresh air. On looking in the Cook’s galley I was astonished to see the Sucani "Smiling Morn" asleep in front of the fire with an over coat on. Evidently Hades would be a home for him. Going down the engine room the heat was so great that one’s temples feel like bursting. The engineer on watch was sitting at his desk his head held between his hands. The speaking tube in communication with the bridge whistled & getting up he went to it. "Give us another revolution" came from above, & going to the controlling levers he increased the speed to the required amount. Huge cranks moved up & down with a clank, clank, clank, making an awful noise, yet this one man has complete control of the whole machinery that towered up to the skylights. A few grimy coolies emerged from the stoke hold covered in coal dust & with burnt hair, their beady

eyes flashing as they passed. "Cassib (storeman) get me a lamp" he called to one. "Yes sahib". (sarb) From the boilers there was a throbbing that, to one unused to it, made one’s head ache. It was too hot for me so I left. At 9.30 am the A13 crossed "the line" in thick misty rain. Various remarks were made referring to it, several "feeling the bump" Teddy of course must play a lark & put a fine hair across the lenses of Mathias’s field glasses so that he could "see" the equator. It was very amusing to see the soldiers shave one another in the hairdressing saloon which was simply an unoccupied horse stall with a few bags of chaff in it. On the wall was written "We do not give matches to Bums." Great amusement was also caused by the soldiers having a bath, the water being turned off just as they are covered in soap. It was necessary to wipe it off in such cases & the disgust of the bather was very great.
Entry.40:
Unlucky 13 again. It may here to be mentioned that on 13th of October chicken pox broke out in Hobart on the A13. Thirteenth day in Hobart the Second officer & Teddy were blown out towards the 

heads. Thirteen white ship’s officers on the A13 & I was the 13th of the list. Today fire broke out on HMAT Karroo & some of her forage was badly damaged by fire & water. The Karroo & several Australian transports with the NZ transports were sent ahead to Colombo.
Entry.41:
A beautiful sunrise was the advent of a "snorter" of a day. The sun rose like a ball of polished brass & the rays almost burnt into one’s flesh. It was the most trying day so far. It was also probable that the convoy was in what is termed by wireless authorities a "dead zone" as the signals were so weak as to be practically unreadable. The horses also were very restive & plunged & stamped, thus adding to the difficulties. It was necessary to close the cabin door to shut out the noise. I was trying to sleep but it was impossible. Teddy struggled to hear the messages & the perspiration ran off his forehead in big drops. My pyjama coat was wringing wet with perspiration & sleep was out of the question. I relieved him for a while but it was impossible to decipher the signals. On the Orvieto the operator is situated on the bridge away from all disturbances but on the A13 we were in a cabin without any

ventilation or light as the ship’s dynamo is stopped during the day. Being on the same deck as the horses did not add to the chance of receiving weak signals. Engine room temperature 120 degrees. Deck 92° & cabins 87°.
Entry.42:
At 5.30 a.m. I went up on the bridge with a message. It was so cool that I stayed there chatting to the Chief Officer. I thought I could smell spices or curry powder & remarked about it, being informed that we were not far from Ceylon. A few seconds later I noticed Point de Galle lighthouse on the southern end of Ceylon. The Chief Officer’s vision must have been warped for he had been "looking for this light for hours." As day broke the land became clearer. Seen through a telescope it appears as if shrouded in heavy mists. Numbers of dhows & catamarans were passed. They were fishing & one dhow had hooked a shark & was getting a lively time. Serang was looking at the island with longing eyes as it is near his home, so I ventured to ask ‘What place is that Serang". The answer I got was indicative of his patriotic spirit. "Killarney sahib" was his reply. Special radio messages were sent

regarding the instructions for anchoring in unison on arrival as all Colombo would be out to see the transports arrive. At two p.m. the convoy drew into Colombo & on a gun being fired on the Flagship the whole convoy anchored. At Colombo there are no wharves so we were required to anchor outside the breakwater.

Colombo

Colombo is a very pretty little town situated on the foreshores. There is no harbour, as the place is open to the sea. A breakwater however provides a shelter from the disastrous monsoons. Looking ashore, the appearance is very pretty. A long beach faces the sea, on the right of which stands a large red brick building owned by Lipton’s Tea Co, surrounded by grass lawns & tall palm trees. A railway runs through an avenue of palms & disappears in the distance. Rickshaws may be seen in scores on the roads that lead through well kept lawns. All the men wear white suits & white helmets as the heat is severe. The Government buildings are bright red & show with striking 

contrast against the yellow & green foliage in the forests in the background. Away in the distance can be seen the blue hills, shrouded in mists. Many flags were flying from the buildings to mark the arrival of the convoy. A very large hotel near the beach is pure white & has several rows of bow windows. On the left is the Governor’s residence standing in a cleared space between the tall palms & the forest. It was here, to our utter disgust that Captain Von Müller of the Emden was banqueted by the authorities. Cingalees parade the streets in white "nighties" & a black "gamp" which makes a very comical picture. It is very hard to distinguish between male & female Cingalee but if one is working it is safe to assume that it is a female. The females carry baskets of coal to the railway trucks whilst the men sit down & smoke. Quaint old barges move slowly about the transports & "bum-boats" as usual are plentiful. Cingalees row out in their boats & for a trifling sum they do washing that is a credit to some done in our cities. Two Cingalees rowed out amongst the transports but were turned away.
Entry.43:
A radio

was sent to the A13 to proceed to the inner harbour for water. The captain & second officer were ashore so the Chief officer & the pilot navigated the A13 through the narrow gates in the breakwater. These pilots are British & live in luxury. They have a native to carry their small hand bag & they themselves are dressed in spotless uniforms of white & polished buttons. In the harbour (inner) which is simply a portion protected by three breakwaters, were the Japanese cruiser Ibuki, & the British cruiser Yarmouth. Outside, was the quaint old Russian cruiser Askold with her five tall thin funnels. The inner harbour was packed with transports & not very far away was the Anglo Egyptian who was just moving out towards the outside transports. Suddenly she dropped both anchors & went "full astern" but too late. With a crash she struck the breakwater near the gates, sending up a shower of spray. The tugboat Goliath immediately went to her assistance & towed her near the shore for fear she would settle down. The damage was practically speaking slight & she afterwards took up her position outside. In absolute silence H.M.A.S. Sydney steamed down the lines of transports & took up her berth. No cheering

was allowed on account of the wounded Germans on the Sydney. Two Cingalees then came out in a barge & dived for money, & never did they miss the coin. Sharks will not touch black races so they have no fear of them. Quaint old rowing boats were pulled about the inner harbour by perhaps eight Cingalees who sit, two in a seat. The helmsman chants a few words & they reply in a chant at the same time pulling on their oars, which look like the ace of spades on a propstick. They row rythmetically & it is quite a novel sight. For perseverance they would be hard to beat as one Cingalee was trying to row a barge of ashes by himself. For some minutes the barge would not move & it then gradually moved away & it was beyond his power to stop it then as it collided with a buoy. A water barge & a steam pump came alongside the A13 at dark & began to fill the ship’s tanks. Chippy the carpenter was given the job of looking after the operation. The soldiers were forbidden to go ashore but some slid down the hawsers & went ashore. Next day they were fined £1 each, as a roll-call was taken after dark.
Entry.44:
At two am I took my watch feeling "up to putty" as I had had

very little sleep on the way from Albany on account of the restive horses & the heat. However I amused myself as best I could to pass the time away. From 2 am till daylight seemed a week sometimes. Suddenly there was a hubbub & shouts of "hey panea (parnee) wallah" (water boy) from Chippy who had been asleep & had just awakened & found that the panea wallah had also gone to sleep & the pump had almost stopped. As no answer came Chippy dropped a great lump of wood on the roof where the water boys were asleep. The result was good for several of them came tearing out, one hitting his head on the doorway on the way out. Being disturbed so suddenly, they naturally gave vent to their feelings by using Cingalee language that I did not understand but Chippy evidently did for he replied in very strong words. By daylight the tanks were filled & the A13 took up her position with the first & second divisions. At 11 am these two divisions headed for Aden in charge of the cruiser Hampshire (British) or as he called himself "Hants". The third division & the N.Z. transports remained to take water as they were fast boats & could pick up.
Entry.45:
The heat is still stifling & during the afternoon a horse just outside the Marconi Room

& down No 3 hatch began to kick most viciously. The Vet was called & tried to quieten the animal but it got worse & as he said its blood was overheated & it was temporarily mad. It kicked so much & reared about that it was necessary to remove other horses from nearby. The Vet injected some drug time & time again but it had no effect, the horse simply standing shivering with fear & wide open eyes kicking & snorting, until I almost gave up hope of sleeping, but towards midnight it quietened down.
Entry.46:
Another 
schor
 scorching day & a glassy sea. At 10 am there was a cry of Whoa! Whoa! & various other ejaculations from the Chief Officer on the bridge, & at the same time the A13 swung out of line owing to her steering gear failing. The Chief officer of course ran amok & yelled orders by the score. H.M.S. Hampshire however dropped back & came over asking if we needed assistance. In an hour we were on our way back to our position & from astern it was a magnificent sight as it was possible to see the whole convoy.
Entry.47:
A soldier met with an accident today being kicked by a horse which split his chin in two. He was placed in the hospital with another soldier whom we nicknamed oyster eyes on account of his large eyes. 

Oyster eyes although unaware of it, was going to be returned as he was found to have consumption. About 9pm the third division was sighted astern & by midnight they were up in position. As they drew up, I was talking to the Chief Officer about the signalling by morse lamp at the same time reading one to him. He then chimed in after me echoing every letter as though he read it until I lead him astray & he owned up that he was "not too good on it". A coolie had been rather free with Roberts & asked him "What’s time boy". For an answer he got a dot on the snitch with a red paint brush that effectually closed his mouth.
Entry.48:
At two a.m. it was stifling with the heat which was increasing each day. I was sitting on the rail in my "panjamas" having some air & ready to duck if Captain Jackson should appear, as he often prowled around at any hour. About 4 a.m. I heard a kind of hissing & moaning. Looking ahead, I saw a Very’s light (white rocket) racing skywards. This was a prearranged signal to stand by the radio for urgent message. To show how watchful our signallers were, I had received & delivered the message before he woke up. It was the Euripides of the third division calling his division to stop their engines at once – two men overboard. As it

did not concern our division I waited & shortly afterwards the Orvieto called the first division to stop their engines immediately - & added operators not to leave instruments until further orders. Here was a problem – to send the message up to the bridge & to stay at the instruments. However I left them & called Captain Jackson giving him the message. I was astonished to see him with all his bed clothes on & a kind of coat over him, as if it were cold. "Dammit what do they want to fall overboard at this time of the day for" he asked. I could not explain, & left him to reason it out. As I took up the phones again I heard H.M.S. Hampshire calling the Orvieto & telling the flagship to lead the first division away. The tones were so sharp & precise that I thought the cruiser was about to "blaze away" at someone. The Orvieto thereupon repeated the direction to be taken but several of the sub-flagships "jambed" in & caused me to miss part of it. I was in a fix as we were liable to run the next transport down or be run down, & they all depended on my receiving the message. To add to my anxiety the Second Officer repeatedly called down the ventilator "Anything doing". "Shut up" I yelled back "How can I hear with you yapping". It was 

not very polite but it served the purpose. Luckily the message was repeated & I got the position. Looking outside the door, the transports were rather out of line & the Hampshire & Ibuki had their searchlights on two transports. It was afterwards stated that the Ascanius had collided with the Shropshire & carried away a lifeboat & crumpled her bow somewhat but no men were lost as thought. I felt very shaky after this little item & felt very relieved when we were all on the way once more. The promptness in which the cruisers acted was wonderful & just showed that they were prepared for an emergency. On account of the Euripides constantly jambing it caused great anxiety & had not the cruisers taken the case in hand there may have been worse results. The battleships work their radios very quickly, not in regards actual speed but each message is sent at an even rate & there is no jambing consequently no need to repeat, & by this way they get through their messages smartly. They slip away at times & reappear just as quickly, issue orders, change the course & so on in a steady methodical way. The N.Z. convoys are fitted far better than the Australian. There is less red tape with them consequently more satisfactory results. They are all 

painted a dull slate grey & at night they are absolutely invisible as regards showing lights but the Australian transports are often like a liner with a regular blaze of lights showing. The N.Z. soldiers are well fed & the boats fully manned. The Australians – judging by the A13 & a few others there is room for great improvement. Of course one cannot expect as many comforts on board a transport as on a passenger boat, but there is no excuse for the following: About this time the soldiers began to complain of the tainted food so an enquiry was made with no results – only natural. However the Steward admitted to Teddy & I that when he heard that an inspection was to be made he had the meat 
washed in Condy’s Fluid
 "to kill ‘em". The meat Teddy & I saw being put on H.M.A.S. Geelong in Hobart had an odor that would run rings around bi-sulphide of carbon. It was actually slimy. The substitute – bully beef – well a man would need a carding machine to masticate it with, & enough salt in it to make the men always thirsty. If pounded with a hatchet I believe it would have turned the edge off it & then

resumed its normal shape. Another thing the NZ’s can show the Australian points on is the interest the flagship takes in the transports. Every morning the flagship of the NZ convoy would call all his convoy up & after wishing them "Good morning" (by radio) he would give the warnews & any other messages & replies that may be of interest. The Australian method ---------Cq (all stations) Orders for the day (given) War news will be sent during the afternoon. (too tired now?) The war news I would often get at 3am from a warship perhaps up at Bombay in India or else from Aden. An hour later another message would be sent cancelling the previous one & issuing another which often had to be altered again. I am not prejudiced against the flagship nor anyone in particular, but never-the-less the way orders were issued, was disgusting, also, on the flagship the "heads" (wooden I think) had a special room for this & another for that, & a special stall for so & so’s horse & something else for so & so. To cut a long story short there were enormous sums of money wasted in carrying out each officer’s particular desire, instead of giving them a good serviceable room

& let that suffice. No! Lieut ------- must have green curtains, Major ------ wants two electric lights instead of one. Poor old operators want a 
loan
 of an electric fan – can’t get it, want a small section of sleep – can’t get it.
Entry.49: At 7am the A13 swung out of line again & dropped astern owing to a mishap to the engines. H.M.S Hampshire also stayed with us to render assistance if necessary. As the NZ transports passed ahead, they could be seen firing at a trailing target thereby getting in rifle practice. It had been asked if the Australian transports could alternately drop back a little for rifle practice, but it was turned down – only natural too. Teddy was disgusted with the Australian methods. Pinto the cabin boy now took a little amusement by playing my "stringatina" when I was asleep & singing DO. RE. ME. So. So. until I threatened to break his thick skull & Teddy threatened to "tap him on the boko".
Entry.50:
About 8am H.M.S. Hampshire disappeared astern: to chase a steamer believed to be the Hawkes Bay, & returned later satisfied. At nine am there was the 

welcome cry "Land oh". It was the island of Sokotra off the North east corner of Africa, near the Gulf of Aden. The island is inhabited by several thousand Arabs who are cannibals & live in caves. It is 70 miles long & 20 miles wide – like a huge lozenge. The surface is very rough & the mountains reach far above the clouds. The coast is extremely rough & precipitous & on account of there being no lighthouses it is necessary to keep a sharp look out for Sokotra, especially during the monsoons. It took all the afternoon to pass the island & in the water could be seen numerous sharks that had evidently been brought by the horses. Long pieces of red seaweed like sausage skins were floating about too. This seaweed is luminous at night & looks like large pieces of rhubarb.
Entry.51:
Being in the Gulf of Aden & also near that port, HMS Hampshire & the Orvieto left us & proceeded to Aden. The distress signal was to be used in case of being attacked & the cruiser would return. The soldiers by this time were beginning to get hungry so they were presented with a box of eggs. Snakes: when their hats were knocked off they all began to whistle. They were beauties & did not add to ones appetite. 

The steward had been missing lots of little items lately. I saw the soldiers wrapping themselves around these delicacies in the early hours of the morning. Today the soldiers just helped themselves to the stores as usual only they were hospital stores & they would not have been touched had this been known. Anyhow the signaller posted on the bridge for our benefit (?) grabbed the most important of the stores – a bottle of brandy. He drank it all & must have excited his pugilistic desires for he donned a pair of boxing gloves & toddled up on the bridge to fight the Second Officer against whom he had a grudge. Luckily, for him, the Chief Officer had just relieved the Second officer so he was turned away without any fuss. He then went below deck & fell asleep in a corner. Colonel Hawley had occasion to call the signaller when a muster was called to see who pinched the stores. Buckling on his sword, & getting ready as we supposed for the battle, he was accompanied by several other officers, down to the signaller. Certainly there was a strong smell of liquor so Colonel Hawley tapped the signaller on the shoulder & as he woke up Colonel Hawley 

said "Signaller" "Yess (hic) zir" "You are drunk"!

Signaller – "Yezzur so (hic) am I."

He was proved guilty however & put into a cell. This little episode was the means of revealing a general plan to rob the cabins by a few of the soldiers who were known to have a shady character. They say forewarned is forearmed so anyone caught prowling round the cabins would be arrested & anyone caught inside a cabin may be shot. A coolie was also posted at the saloon door to keep watch. Ether was to have played the part as anaesthetic during the "job".
Entry.52:
At 4 am when the Chief Officer took his watch the Coolie had moved away from the saloon door as he began to Yell Calassey! & when he turned up he docked him one rupee as a caution. Today was the hottest day so far. The sea was like polished silver & there was no wind at all. At 4 pm we drew into single line & entered Aden. What cliffs there were. The land was awful, broken, & nothing but desert as far as the eye could see: The sea board was a mass of precipices such as are not seen in Australia. Away on top of these cliffs was a little building – the signal station – & it looked like a minature doll’s house. At the foot of the cliffs

is Aden radio station which receives all cables from parts of Africa through Berbera radio in Somaliland. They are then cabled onwards from Aden as there are no cables at Berbera. Along the summit of these cliffs are quaint old forts that look like tiny sand castles, no bigger than a pea. Aden township is very small indeed. There are no wharves here as in Colombo also. The heat when anchored was worse than ever & the fumes & smells that came up the hatches was awful. The whole appearance of Aden & its surroundings is "nature unadorned" & is very impressive. Teddy & I were both feeling about done & thought we would be given a night’s rest – no fear of that while Captain Jackson was on board. By asking the other transports by means of the morse lamp on the bridge, whether they were keeping a watch they said no, that the sub-flagships were keeping one. Anyhow we had to whether or no.
Entry.53:
At two am I took my watch again & went outside as it was too warm inside. All the transports were moored in the harbour & at each hour there was a succession of different toned bells as they each struck the hour. At 7 am. the convoy moved out of Aden, great care being necessary in weighing anchor not to foul the submarine

cables. H.I.J.M. Ibuki was left here with H.M.A.S. Melbourne & HMS Hampshire took charge of the convoy. A radio was sent shortly afterwards saying that H.I.J.M. Ibuki was off to South America. Farewells were exchanged by radio & away we steamed towards Suez – a five day’s run up the Red Sea. At 4 pm as we approached Hell’s Gates at the entrance to the red sea between Perim & the African side, special radios were sent & all ensigns, flags & lights were taken in & put out, as the country here belonged to Turkey. Perim is a small low lying island that looks like sun baked mud. Numbers of ships may be seen sunk here. This island is a coaling station & has the reputation of being able to supply coal, ice & Kola (drink) On the left side of Hell’s Gates is Abyssinia & Perim & Syria on the right.
Entry.54:
About 8 am the convoy passed the Twelve Apostle Islands (Turkish) & Jebul Tiere. Another scorcher Engine room temperature 136 degrees. Numbers of Indian transports were passed as they were returning to India for more troops. H.M.A.S. Geelong had recently been giving great trouble in not maintaining his position. At dusk every day the Geelong was in position but by daybreak the next morning the Geelong would be three miles behind.

This was so frequently done that HMS Hampshire threatened to take the Captain off & replace him with one of his own men. The trouble was over the stokers who refused to stoke the fires because beer was 2/6 per bottle & cigarettes 6d 
each
. 

The Geelong was then taken out of the line & some stores were transferred from the Flagship.

That evening some excitement was caused by a soldier attempting to throttle a coolie. The coolies thereupon began to get excited & talked about Kill! Kill! & like words but it was smoothed over but a caution was given the soldiers not to interfere with them. So far there had been no certain orders as to the convoy’s destination but today a message contained the words – When we get to England. Teddy was delighted with the news as he had been eleven months out from England.
Entry.55:
About eleven a.m. a radio was sent from the flagship regarding orders sent from the Admiralty at Whitehall London, concerning our destination. Teddy pricked up his ears & sat up in his bunk as I read the message to him. When I got to the word Alexandria – Egypt his face fell at once, as he expected to hear Southampton. Poor Teddy, it put his appetite off. 

The news was soon around the ship & the soldiers were all eager to get anywhere. The South Australians especially wanted to get on the desert. Frequent empty transports were passed as they thrashed their way back to India for more troops.
Entry.56:
Pass P&O mail steamer outwards bound. The sunrises in the Red sea are absolutely beyond my power to describe. They are supposed to be the second best anywhere in the world. Shortly before sunrise the clouds assume a dark violet colour which is rather lighter in colour towards the edges. As the dawn fades away the clouds gradually change colour & just before the sun rises they appear like great clouds of froth of a beautiful pink tint. The best view is obtained of the clouds over the horizon where the sun rises. As one watches them they gradually change from dark to light green thence to other colours & finally to a crimson shade almost like flames of fire. The sun then rises, & the colours fade away, but instead of the sun being dazzling, it is just like blood & can be seen hanging like a peach as it were. It stays like this perhaps for an hour & then warms up. At dusk it sinks as it were, into the sea, appearing the same blood colour, but the water is 

just like fire & the clouds are all tipped with flame colours. Often for two hours after the sun has set, the sea, which is without a ripple, is like polished copper. The shades of colours are too vivid to describe. Today was the hottest day of all the trip. The engine room registered 140 degrees & to venture down there was like walking into Hades. The fifth engineer cam up after his watch & the perspiration was running off his singlet & trousers which were wet through, & trickling away on the deck. Teddy & I both felt very tired & irritable, especially as the bum sergeant & others would stand outside the cabin door & practice signalling until we were sick of the sound & sight of the morse code. The second officer & the bum sergeant donned a pair of boxing gloves & had a few rounds. There was only one hit split into two parts – "a tap on the boko" & "a job on the solar plexis" & our friend the sergeant cam through the air like a hailstone, ending with a crash against the officer’s cabins.
Entry.57: The weather now began to moderate as we entered the Gulf of Suez, which gradually narrows towards Suez itself. Cool breezes blew over the convoy & once more the awnings were removed from the hatches
Entry.58:
At four am we passed Mt Sinai of biblical interest on the starboard side, which was made the more beautiful by a glorious sunrise shortly afterwards, in which long shafts of golden light appeared to shoot out from the sun like searchlights. The Gulf was now so narrow as to be able to see land on either side. Egypt on the left & the Holy Land on the right. On the Egyptian side was all desert, desolate & barren excepting for an occasional signal station of white stone colour. On the other side was a more desolate land, as Teddy put it, "If that’s the land of milk & honey" then the bees & cows must have a rough time of it." The wind now increased to a stiff breeze & the sea began to rise, but the weather was just magnificent & made us all feel somewhat happier. At two pm we came to Suez which is a very small town indeed. It looked like a "dead-end" to me. 

(Sketch of Suez Bay)

 

A warship was there as a guard & was sheltering in a little cove. All around as far as can be seen is huge sand cliffs & desert, miles & miles of sand. The canal is not visible from the position we are in but looking further inland the ships in the canal appear to be steaming through the desert. We were all very tired & looked forward to having a little rest, but no fear of that on the A13. The operators on the other transports were having a rest & we kept a watch for no purpose whatever. Scores of Bum-boats ply their wares consisting chiefly of Turkish cigarettes, post cards & curios. That night there was a cold blast that almost set us shivering. This is typical weather here. During the day the heat is fierce & at night there is almost a frost.
Entry.59:
At 10 am a fleet of ships was seen coming up astern with a huge warship. It was an Indian convoy being escorted by the French cruiser Dupleix. The convoy contained some beautiful ships of the "Bibby" line that trade to India. As soon as the convoy anchored, the Indians began their physical culture on the decks & through the glasses it could be seen what a magnificent lot of men they were. Not as some may imagine – a lot of dirty black soldiers. 

Their complexion is bronze & their appearance in uniform is a credit to them. Great broad shoulders & knotted muscles that stand out like whip cord. Our own soldiers were delighted with them. The warship "Dupleix" was the most powerful I have ever seen in appearance. She had an enormous beam & short thick funnels, set so low that spark arresters were necessary to protect the decks. The men too were a magnificent lot. As Suez bay is not a very large place one can imagine what an impressive sight it was with all the transports. At three pm the A13 received orders to enter the canal. A very nice French pilot came out shortly after & the A13 set out for Port Said. The convoy was now broken up & each transport took its own way & was to call for help if necessary & a warship would always be nearby. As we passed Suez township which is very small a lot of little Egyptian children were coming out of school & were singing. Several Moorish women also stood on the bank of the canal which appears to wind up the main street. A curios sight was the fact that some Egyptian students were parading the street dressed up to "dicky" with canes, gloves, felt fur hats & cigarettes. An armed guard was now placed on each transport to reply to any hostile firing later 

as some 30,000 Dervishers were supposed to be about to attack the canal. Soldiers in their dark uniforms with red piping, their faces as black as night stood to attention in their sentry boxes as night stood to attention in their sentry boxes as the transports passed & were cheered by all the men. On the right bank is the awful desert as far as the eye can see, with an occasional Arab & his camel slowly plodding along through the thick sand. The Arabs & Egyptians dress alike & wear trousers of ample size the seat of which reaches to their ankles, a waistcoat & coat of the brightest colours, filthy dirty too & on their heads the Arabs generally wear a coloured handkerchief & a few stray beads etc. They are very much like the pirates we read of in boy’s books. The canal is just wide enough for two boats to pass – one being tied to the bank. In about an hour we were well out of the township & had the desert on either side. Shortly after leaving Suez we passed a French Steamer the Eugene Crocos who was tied to the bank to allow the transports a free way. There were several French ladies on board & as may be expected, they received a hearty cheer as we passed. Their reply was a perfect shower of kisses & such emotional exclamations as "Good, brave

Australians" They threw their handkerchiefs & flowers to the men & it is well that it only took a few seconds to pass as there was every possibility of them shedding their hats & boots & throwing them. I tried very hard to get a handkerchief but missed it. The old French Chef – as fat as an alderman – stood in the galley doorway & threw kisses, picking them off his lips (
like
) with little jerks. At 6 pm, we drew into Great Bitter lake & as we had no searchlight we dropped anchor till morning. On navigating the Suez canal it is necessary for a steamer to have a searchlight, which is picked up at either Suez or Port Said before entering the canal. The searchlight is fixed in the bow of the steamer & throws a diverging beam of light that lights up either bank & thereby aids navigation. The canal has an average depth of 30 feet & at night it is very pretty steaming through. One side is lit at intervals with red lights & green on the other, both being in the water & mark the limit for vessels to approach the banks. On the left side for a time after leaving Suez is a long stretch of thick undergrowth with trees that are reflected in the glassy surface of the canal. Steamers cannot steam at full speed through the canal as their screws stir up the bottom so it is necessary to go half speed & then stop until the 

momentum needs another "kick". Great Bitter lake is about 20 miles from Suez & the canal runs through it. It was a glorious moonlight night & the other transports with searchlights could be seen slowly steaming as it seemed through the desert, showing a great shaft of dazzling light. I was feeling about "done" for want of sleep & the excitement I think bore me up somewhat. Tiny canal boats kept watch over the canal all night. They are beautiful little gunboats, perfect in proportions & as an idea as to their dimensions it may be noted that the funnel is about 10 feet high & their beam is about 12 feet. They can travel about 36 knots & have a very shallow draught, suitable for the smooth waters of the canal but too small to venture into rough seas.
Entry.60:
At two a.m. we were alone it seemed in the desert. The stillness was intense & the bright moon was reflected in the water as in a mirror. Three am there was a clang-clang, clang-clang,-clang-clang, as the sucani struck the hour. How desolate it looked, the awful solitude of the vast desert almost playing on one’s nerves. The soldiers were all asleep on the foredeck, their faces easily discernible in the moonlight. Looking aft from here there was only one person awake it appeared & that was the sucani who dozed on the 

bridge. The pilot lay asleep on the saloon settee & the Second officer was fast asleep in his clothes on his settee. How I envied them, not that they got more than I, although they certainly had more time, but I was at the stage of "passed sleep" & felt physically tired & yet my head was working away quite easily. I longed to crawl into my bunk in the quietness & have an hour or two. No watch was necessary, but it was only Captain Jackson’s cussedness that kept us up. Daybreak was the most magnificent I have ever seen. On one side the moon was setting as it seemed into the lake & gave the lake & shore a decidedly green colour & on the opposite side the sun was giving the clouds a pink tinge & the desert seemed shrouded in a crimson mist caused by the reflections of the sun’s rays over the desert. Gradually the green disappeared & gave way to the rising sun which rose like a huge transparent red ball. All the beautiful paintings & pictures in Art Galleries cannot compare with the soft colours of these sunrises & sunsets which change from one colour to another & are so soft in hues in tints as to be totally different from the usual Australian sunrises & sunsets which are generally a blaze of dazzling light. At 6am the A13 weighed anchor & 

entered the canal again. On passing through the Bitter Lakes there were several Egyptians shooting ducks with antiquated shot guns & each time a gun went off, the soldiers would jump, thinking it was being fired at the transport. On the left bank of the canal are signal stations at about 5 mile intervals & these stations pass word to steamers on the advice of another steamer passing. On the right bank were garrisons of English & Indian troops, quite close enough to speak to. The Indian troops would signal messages to the transports by means of flags & their sending was perfect & a pleasure to read. As we came to a deep cutting where the banks rise somewhat higher than the steamer, we could see the machine guns trained on the canal, field guns, sand bag forts, & barbed wire entanglements at the rear to prevent an attack from that quarter. The Indian sentries stood like carven stone, their hands folded over the muzzle of their rifle & their dark eyes looking straight to the front. A fine lot of men indeed but very ferocious looking. Then the English Tommies with their "broad" speaking, all quite happy & with smiling faces. It was very comforting to know that they were not enemies. The Indian troops’ English officers are easily picked out by their 

upright carriage & sharp words. On the left bank were Egyptian boys employed with camels in widening the canal. They wear a kind of nightgown & a fez cap. They sometimes have donkeys drawing trucks of sand over temporary rails & in this proceedure they do not spare the donkey but belabour it with great waddies of wood. The camels have boxes (two) on his back & kneels down until they are filled. It is then led away & emptied. Numerous dredges are employed in keeping the correct depth, manned by Frenchmen. The dredges are wonderful & are kept beautifully clean. A long pipe arm reaches over the bank of the canal to well back from the bank. The deposit is then pumped through this large tube to the rear. Numbers of Egyptian boys threw themselves down the canal banks yelling all kinds of fury against Germans & exclamations of -S"Good English". It was nice to know that even here there were friends. As the transports pass through the canal, a small tidal wave precedes each steamer owing to the displacement of water. At one pm word was received from a signal station to tie up to the bank to allow a French cruiser to pass. The last thirty miles of the Suez canal is in a "dead" straight line & from the transport it appears like a long path. Slowly the French cruiser the Desaix drew nearer. Our 

men were drawn up on the boat deck & stood to attention. When passing, which the cruiser did very slowly so as not to draw us into the bank, we dipped our ensign as a mark of respect & she returned the salute by slowly lowering her huge ensign (French) & hoisting it again. At the same time our soldiers came to Present Arms & the French sailors stood to attention the length of the ship. The Admiral was on the bridge, and was in full dress uniform with medals & gold braid galore. He was an elderly man with snow white hair & clear features. Cheers & hearty ones, then broke out from both vessels, & the cruiser gradually drew astern. As she passed the men could be seen asleep near the guns & the cleanliness of the cruiser was magnificent. Every piece of brass & copper shone with a brilliant lustre & the decks were as white as milk. As the distance widened, a bugle on the cruiser sounded some unfamiliar call evidently French & our bugler replied with "Reveille", but why this mournful call nobody knows. It was a stirring sight & will never be forgotten by those who saw it. As Port Said is approached it is possible to see the Suez Express train which runs quite close to the bank on the left side. It winds itself through the thick undergrowth near the canal 

at this particular spot. In appearance it seems smaller by far than NSW railways, but for speed it could run rings round NSW. At 2 pm we drew into Port Said at the Mediterranean end of the Suez Canal. The first noticeable feature is the great number of steamers in the small harbour. Warships & aeroplanes were here in plenty. HMS. Swiftsure, one of England’s large warships was here & maintained control. Small torpedo boats, cruisers, destroyers, submarines & other craft were here & there. Two huge French cruisers were anchored not very far off. Port Said Radio (S.U.B.) was only a quarter of a mile away & when this station was transmitting, it was possible to read the message by listening to the sparks crackling across the condenser protective gaps, which shows the power being radiated. As the strength threatened to burn out the phones it was necessary to earth the ariel. Two large French aeroplanes were throbbing violently on the quay. The way the small war craft keep in touch with headquarters may be interesting. Each of the cruisers & other vessels have a particular call signal for this purpose. Take one (name not known) who’s call was G9. This vessel also has a certain time, say seven minutes past the hour & seven minutes past the half hour. At this time 
punctually
 this cruiser will call G.9. – nothing more. The operator on the 

warship in charge knows the time & call of each cruiser & as each one gives its call on the given time it is known that all is well. Should a vessel fail to report on time there is a search made immediately. Captain Jackson went ashore & arranged for coal, but in the meantime two barges were alongside & were coaling. A message was also sent saying that the A13 was not to be coaled so the Chief Officer ran yelling Whoa! Whoa! Stop! Stop! & so on until the whole transport was in an uproar. Things were put right later & the work of coaling began again. The Egyptians place two long beams of wood up against the transports from the coal barges. One plank is used for the upward journey & the other for the return. The coal is carried in small baskets & is tipped down the hatches, the method being very tedious & slow but with the numbers employed it is remarkable the amount of work done in a few hours. During this operation however the Egyptians set up a continuous howl & yell that is deafening & strange to say, the more noise they make the faster they work. Operations are also carried out by oil lamps & with the awful noise & being tired as I was I was forced to try & get away from it all as my nerves were so far gone that I felt I could cry, big as I was. Teddy was very drawn & had dark rings under his eyes & we each knew 

that things were getting too strong. We were both strung up & began to realise that if things continued much longer we would either break down or perhaps make an error that may lead to disaster. So far we had succeeded in avoiding errors, but now, in our present state it may occur easily. Relief came at last. HMS. Swiftsure said "Transport operators need not keep a watch tonight as I am keeping a continual watch." We were delighted with the news but imagine our thoughts when Captain Jackson refused us & said, "Better keep one in case of accident". I leave the question of the sense of this & also his thoughtfulness of us to the reader. We were disgusted, but swore to be even with him by not receiving war news & in not telling him all the news of interest we were capable of. We had now been 52 days out from Hobart & out of mere consideration may have been given a rest – no fear of that on the A13. An error on our part & possibly hundreds of lives may be lost. I do not wish to overestimate an operator’s position but the reader can form his or her own opinion, on this matter. Teddy was very concerned about the Second Steward who abhorred water. He had not had a bath, to our knowledge, since we left Sydney & as Teddy put it he "whooped through this boots" an expression that certainly conveys his state to the reader. He was rather deaf so it was safe to talk without him hearing. He had a way of 

heaping his plate with fish, meat, & pudding in several heaps on the one plate. As one course was finished a slight turn of 60 degrees & the next course is ready to be attacked. Harbour traffic in Port Said is extremely heavy & it is well worth watching the natives handle their boats. They run great risks though one boat getting within a few feet of a transport’s propeller which began to revolve & almost cut them to pieces. The A 13’s propeller by the way weighs 4 tons. They managed to evade the screw however at the same time yelling like maniacs. In Port Said it is safe to call any Egyptian Hassan or Abdhul as they are nearly all these names. Teddy invited Hassan to cut his hair after he (Teddy) had ascertained his qualifications. As they seemed good Teddy gave the word to "Let her go" Snakes & didn’t Hassan go it. He had a number of soldiers waiting & at 6 a time he was making his fortune. He simply grabbed it in one hand & lopped it off with a pair of scissors that had been used on cutting sheet iron. Teddy spat it out of his mouth & groaned as the scissors got stuck & tore the hair out. In a few minutes Hassan had finished & began blowing the hair off Teddy’s head, until Teddy had to tell him to "mahanna jow". A few Egyptian conjourers gave displays in their rowing boats 

as they came alongside & considering their limited space it was very well executed. The soldiers of course bought "appeels" "orangess" & "Turkish delart" from the bumboat man. It is very funny to hear the bartering. A bumboat comes alongside with his wares, generally fruit, postcards, cigarettes, & clothes (& if one whispers "whisky" he can generally find a bottle under a seat). Well the bumboat man throws a rope up on deck with a basket attached & if one wants to buy an article it is necessary to ask "How much so & so?" "Two sheeling" comes the answer "Too dear Abdhul" "One seex" back again from Abdhul "No! only ninepence Abdhul" & the latter will reply "No, No sar". Pretend to go away & Addhul quickly shouts "All right, send money down" (no tick from them) "Cost me three sheeling, but me good man" so forth & so on. The soldiers had a much more effective way, as follows:- "How much oranges" – "Two sheeling dozen" – "Send one up & let me taste it." The bait takes & one is sent up for a sample. As soon as the bumboat comes alongside & is under the soldiers, two of the latter hold a beam of wood over the bumboat & threaten to drop it on top of the bumboat if they try to get away, or if they don’t pass them up at say sixpence a doz. It works admirably & when finished buying, the bumboat man generally gets a bucket of water emptied over him as a 

parting shot. The Egyptians are very coarse in appearance & in manner and are most ignorant, except in the arts of deceiving & thieving. This only applies to a certain class of the race, as there are some very well educated Egyptians. I was walking past old Chippy’s cabin when I heard a volley of language, so I went to see what the trouble was over & found Hassan the barber whilst flourishing a razor about had cut Chippy’s finger & Chippy was calling him rather bad names. Hassan’s only reply was "All right soon – not deep" but Chippy thought otherwise. A fine building is the Suez Canal Buildings which has two domes inlaid with mosaic. At 11pm the coaling operations had been completed & silence once again reigned. I had a little sleep up till 2 am
Entry.61:
when I again took my watch. The harbour was full of transports & at each hour there was a medley of bells, some deep & some cracked. HMS Swiftsure could only be placed by her searchlight which was kept on the canal. The town was in darkness & the only sign of life was a stray call of "Abdhul" followed by a string of Hindustani. About 4 a.m. H.M.A.T. Karroo shifted her berth & in the operation a barge almost got destroyed through coming too near her screw. 

At 7am the A13 was ordered to anchor 3 miles out of the harbour. As we slowly passed the remaining transports cheer after cheer went up from both sides. The A13 was accompanied by one of the tiny canal boats which, when we anchored, kept a watch over us. During the morning a message was sent to all transports as follows:- 

"A torpedo boat will visit the transports & assistant operators will be transferred to HMS Swiftsure & thence to HMAT Karroo & will be returned to Sydney." In a way I was pleased but yet very dissappointed. However, Captain Jackson immediately communicated with the Flagship & said that I was not a naval rating & that I was a member of the ship’s crew. On this, I was ordered to remain. As evening fell, the little torpedo boats kept in close for fear of submarines as we were now in the Mediterranean.
Entry.62:
At 6pm the A13, under cover of night, weighed anchor & headed for Alexandria on the mouth of the river Nile. Again the Swiftsure gave permission for the operators to have a rest but Captain Jackson – "There may be some German warships about." Supposing so – could we get away? could we fight them when there were 

only three rifles & a few revolvers on board. We were absolutely disgusted & for some time Captain Jackson’s ears must have burned. The Chief Officer came into the cabin for a smoke after dinner & he offered to call us should captain Jackson prowl around, but in view of the risks we kept watch. To see "how it would work", every morning when Captain Jackson would ask "any news" the answer would be "Not a sound all night as the warships are coding all messages". It never had any effect, beyond showing that "someone" on board felt rather uneasy about Germans. Of course the Chief Officer would occasionally see strange sights – through not using enough water in his cough mixture – & would enlarge on them, until he swore he saw a submarine & naturally everyone "Kidded him on" & then laughed at him.
Entry.63:
At 5 am the soldiers were preparing to disembark & at 9 am the coast line could be seen on the horizon. As we drew near Alexandria, a boat put off with a pilot & met us. The pilot boat, as usual, worked past the A 13 & came up astern & almost got chopped 

 

up by the A13’s propeller. A gangway was lowered & the pilot boarded. He wore a long frock tailed coat, grey trousers & a fez cap. The other pilots in the boat all sat like Hindus with their legs crossed & arms folded. When the pilot took charge, the A13 drew slowly into the harbour. Occasionally here was a sound of "Dammit" which was Captain’s mild expression of annoyance. His full blown outburst of language was unprintable. 

Alexandria is practically open to the sea, & has a number of breakwaters to protect the harbour. 

(Sketch of Alexandria harbour)

The harbour was full of boats including twenty six German prize steamers all heavily laden. The N.Z. transports were unloading & had occupied all the available wharf space so we were forced to remain at anchor some three miles from the town. During the afternoon Captain Jackson sent word that as there was no flagship in the harbour we need not keep a watch. Snakes! you should see the way we got to bed, clothes & all after making Pinto the cabin boy bring refreshments & gave him strict instructions not to dare & open the door. The weather was ideal & we slept until well after dinner when we got dressed & went ashore in a bum-boat. I will now try & describe our visit to Alexandria. The trip ashore was novel. The boat was just an ordinary rowing boat, somewhat larger & stronger with a single mast & a leg of mutton sail. The Arab rowed all the way & the second officer steered. The Captain had previously "coughed up two of the brightest" all round & told us not to get into mischief. The first thing I noticed was the few lights in the streets, the awful hovels, & the vile smells. The streets were almost all cobblestones & were full of puddles of 

water. The smell was awful & reminded one of bi-sulphide of carbon – which is perfume compared to the back streets of Alexandria. We met a few Gendarmes in the street & after enquiring for Rue de Gameli were put on the track for the main street. On entering this main street the surroundings were much better. The Second officer, & several others went one way & Teddy, Roberts & myself went further into the town. I admit I was all eyes & rather excited. Such strange sights – In a grocer’s shop were several of the Arabs squatting on the floor smoking. The curios & peculiar dress of the inhabitants all kept my mind filled. Music there was plenty of some very good & some awful. As we neared the centre of the town the noise & hubbub increased & with the quaint eastern scents & the incense & other queer attractions I felt almost carried away. Electric trams tear along the street at a pace that puts Sydney trams out of sight, the driver jumping on the bell & making the people scatter in all directions. The trams have two cars – the front one for Europeans & the rear for natives. As the town is almost inhabited by natives the rear car was always full. Should an Arab dare & enter the European’s car 

he was immediately hauled out. The Arabs wear long trousers as before stated & the Egyptians wear a nightgown affair & the men are often bare footed. Dainty little French girls in the shops were all on for a lark with the newcomers & were continually cracking jokes, & smiling in a fascinating way. Their peculiar walk, with their neat dress & hair "upholstered" in the latest fashion & their lovely pink fingers were enough to entice anyone. As this city is the most notorious city in the world we had to be very careful, especially so not to be lured to the native quarters as this often ends with fatal results. I had a "squirt" in my hip pocket & Teddy had a French dagger. I was awakened from my dream as it were by someone clutching my coat & turning round I saw an awful sight. By appearances, a young girl of perhaps twenty, a dreadful deformity with a baby in her arms begging for money. The poor thing turned up two eyes that had a cataract on them & the expression was pitiful. Teddy gave her some & she hobbled away. I can see her now at times & it was the most pitiful sight I ever saw. As soon as Teddy produced 

money to give her we were besieged from all sides by a horde of nightgowned spectres fighting to get near us & yelling Sair! Sair! & putting out a fist for "the dibbs". They were soon scattered by a policeman. I then fastened my eyes on a rather handsome Egyptian young woman who wore a bamboo affair with three brass rings down her nose & her face was covered from her eyes down. A vicious prod in the region of my refreshment room brought me to my senses as Teddy cautioned me to "eyes off". It is very silly to admire the married girls in Egypt as a faithful husband will not hesitate to put the damper on intruding affections by means of a knife. After that lesson I resorted to my old ways & kept them away – well away. Arabs & Bedouins do not value a human life any more than we do a fly’s life, so to ask for trouble is very unwise. Suddenly an Arab boy appeared as if from out of the ground – like Sydney tram troubes in an accident – & said for "Seexpence" he would take us to the pictures & a concert. "Let her go then" & he walked well ahead & we kept him in sight, following him through street after street until he took us to a low flat roofed building. On "coughing up 9d each" we were 

ushered into the hall & immediately saw our mistake, but it was too late. The only other whites in the building were two officers off the troopship Ascanius, so we moved over & sat behind them in case of trouble we would be together. They were anxious to get out too so we arranged to get up shortly & leave. Suddenly the musicians opened up the chorus on stringatinas & mandolins & the whole audience began to chant to it. The noise was awful & the vicious looks on their faces made me feel very uncomfortable & to add to my discomfit I found that the Arab boy who led us here was seated behind us & would not budge. Coffee was brought on a tray – very small cups – & with a glass of water which cost 1/- a cup &, as we believed, it was drugged so we left it. An Arab had evidently misbehaved himself for two Egyptians held the doors open & a Gendarme with fierce eyes & a thick moustache grabbed him by the scruff of the neck & the seat of his trousers & literally threw him out & down the steps into the street. The Arab boy behind us still pestered us to have a "hubble-bubble" (a pipe much the same as an Indian Hookah)

but we declined with thanks & got up quietly & left, as there was every possibility of a brawl. Our friend the Arab boy still pursued us in his nightie but he flew for his life when Teddy threatened to break his head – if he could. On the return to the A13 we saw some brawls in the hotels & several Australian soldiers "outed" for the time, & arrived on board at 1 am.
Entry.64: We stayed on board all day & slept. At about 5 pm Captain Jackson called for me & told me that I was to return to Australia on H.M.A.T. Star of Victoria. As before, I was pleased & yet sorry to leave as Teddy was a jolly kind fellow & we got on very well together, but it was useless to protest so I packed up ready to leave.
Entry.65:
After breakfast Captain Jackson sent work to me to go to the chart room & arrange about leaving. This was all arranged & we (Captain & I) were just leaving for the Consul’s office to sign off when a Naval officer came aboard to see Captain Jackson. That was my fate. In a few minutes I was called to the Captain’s room & entered. The room was full of smoke from cigars & a smell of "fire water". The Naval officer rose & began "Er-er- I believe you are to return to Australia by H.M.A.T. Star of Victoria & er-er

"there is not much room on her & er-er- as Cap(hic)tain Jackson says, I think you may (hic) remain. Thank you that will do & Captain Jackson just winked the tiniest little wink – he won & he knew it. Teddy was very pleased & even helped me unpack. I said many nasty things as this was the third time I had packed up & had to unpack again. Packing is a woman’s work. A man cannot "get ’em all in", but by Teddy’s & my strength we managed it. To celebrate the event, Teddy Second Officer, Electrician, & self went ashore. At 2 am
Entry.66:
we started for home in a garry (pronounced garee) & by an officious guide who called himself Gallagher we found ourselves miles from "home". At 4.00 am we found a boat & were rowed outside the breakwater, as the wind & rain were rather too strong to beat against, & then beat back into the harbour. As all the transports were in darkness we could not find the A 3 until about 4.30 am, when, wet through & stone cold we boarded & crawled into our bunks. At eleven am a pilot took us into a wharf & the horses were disembarked. They were very frisky & broke away

at times, but for all that they were very weak & could not be ridden for quite a month. The Arabs were a continual nuisance & several times the policeman had to hunt them away. I went for a run up Alexandria in a garry with some letters & had a prowl round the town. One incident I forgot to mention is that while anchored at Alexandria in the harbour an Egyptian custom’s launch came alongside & at twelve noon the crew, one by one knelt on the deck & prayed, their faces towards Mecca according to the Mahommedan religion. Time & time again they bowed & scraped until their foreheads touched the deck & no doubt to the majority of us it was a peculiar sight, but no one interfered with them in their prayers.
Entry.67:
There was another farewell just before night as the soldiers off the A13 came & said goodbye. O’Reilly, Mathias, Scotty & others all turned up & we assured them that they had our best wishes & that we would return to Australia for more men. They parted with every confidence of success & we all hope they get it (success I mean). More trouble for the Saloon cook – a native from Colombo where we engaged him – absconded & left us without one. So far I had only received one short letter from home whilst in Port Said – a postcard. 

Teddy had not had any for some months & was very dissappointed. 

13th December At three p.m. Roberts who was very unsatisfied with his position on board, & who had been planning to "skin out", quietly packed up his duds & left. At 4 pm the Captain missed him & a search was made. Naturally we knew nothing whatever. As he could not be found, the Consul was notified & at 4.30 pm the A13 drew out from the wharf & turned towards Port Said again. When past the danger zone, the pilot was taken off & we streamed away to Port Said.
