13th December A gentle breeze was blowing as we turned from Alexandria & I felt so happy that we were returning. The A 13 was in very light trim & was vibrating badly as her propeller was half out of the water. Our watches began once more & Captain Jackson asked that we keep a sharp watch etc, etc, in case of Germans.
Entry.69:
At 8 am the A 13 drew near Port Said & waited for a pilot but as none came we entered on our own. A long breakwater extends out from Port Said & in the centre of this breakwater is a large bronze statue of De Lesseps – the French engineer who constructed the Suez Canal. Our berth was in the usual place for the mail steamers. As soon as breakfast was over we sauntered out to have a look around. The ship was fairly clean now & the coolies were putting the finishing touches. Fratelli – the famous mandoline expert came on board & tried to sell them but we were "dry". He played Il Trovatore on a mandoline beautifully & that was enough to make anyone buy an instrument but, as I said, we were "dry". Ostrich feather men then boarded & gave us a fine time pestering us to buy. "Ah! do sair, I have a wife & family & cannot pay the rent, & other 

woful tales that would not take. One was a cross between an Egyptian & a Jew. His "conk" betrayed the "Yid" in him. He wanted me to buy a boa for £2/10/- but it was more like a long bottle brush than a boa. Another Egyptian with a "snout" like a plum duff produced some feathers & a fan which I beat him down from 15/- to 10/6 for two feathers & two fans – his original price being feathers 15/- each, fans
Entry.70:
each. That was the best bargain I ever made, but it cost several hours wrangling. Water was pumped into the A 13’s tanks & at 4 pm the pilot flag was hoisted. Shortly afterwards, an old pilot boarded & away we steamed. A searchlight had been provided & as we entered the canal it was lighted. I was very interested in the generator for this light, it being a French pattern with a long, thin, but very massive commutator that delivers 70 amps at 100 volts to the light. An Arab boatman is also taken through in case it be necessary to tie up at any time. This man caused great trouble by pestering everyone to buy "Turkish delart", - good stuff only made with the feet. I intended to state that the searchlight generator is driven by turbine coupled to a steam pipe & revolves at a very high speed. The land on either side of the Canal had 

been flooded to prevent the enemy from reaching the Canal. As the sun set, it turned this water into a colour like molten metal, the most beautiful tint imaginable & all the A13 seemed to be bathed in golden light. This lasted for two hours after sunset but with it came a perfect plague of mosquitos that were very small but sting – why they were on a par with rattlesnakes & death adders. Teddy & I sought refuge in front of the Second officer’s electric fan, as the little devils could not hang on in the wind. It was very pretty sailing through the canal, the searchlight showing off either bank. The same garrisons of troops were passed & the sentries could be seen walking up & down the summit of the bank as they kept guard over the soldiers sleeping. What an insight it was. War, in its grim reality, not camp time when sentries may be bribed with a bottle of "fiz". Failure to answer the sentry satisfactorily meant death. Failure to obey a warship & that also meant a warning shell & anything further of course was a hole that could not be darned. Yes! Orders were to be obeyed now & no evading them either. No two chances, no arguing, just to be obeyed. 

Suez was reached at 6.30 am & the pilot & searchlight were taken off. A half an hour was spent waiting for letters & possibly Roberts but as neither appeared, the engine room telegraph rang "Full ahead" & gradually Suez – the place that fascinated me because of its rugged situation – gradually faded out of sight. HMAT Saldanha was ahead of us & H.M.A.T. Hymettus followed in our rear. Photography on board was a great trial. When everything was ready there was a pillow stuffed up the little ventilator & towels etc hung over the port-hole. When the A 13 lurched it meant hypo over everything & when Teddy did any developing it was a perfect mess of liquids & ejaculations of "Isn’t it a bonzer"? "Yes! What is it?" Venus of Milo in a snowstorm" "Psyche in the bathtub" etc etc. Teddy was a good photographer – yes a bonzer.
Entry.71: The weather was becoming warm again & we did not look forward to it either. The A 13 was being painted from stem to stern & was clean & tidy once again. I missed the soldiers now & time seemed to hang more heavily than when they were on board. The
Entry.72:
Engineer broke out in a rash & was placed in the isolation hospital for fear he had infectious sickness. The only chance he got to 

roam about was during the small hours of the morning & at about three am he would appear at the door of our cabin clad in a singlet & white trousers & would sit down on the step & yarn away until daylight when he would creep back to the hospital. He was Scotch & was always praising the Heilanders. Several others of the white crew were Scotch & Teddy & I used to visit their mess room & listen to their tales & such beauties they were. The Chief Steward was in bed with a touch of fever & was very bad. He was English & when he began to spout it was time to knock off as he would yap – yap – yap & drown everybody else. His great fear was Germans. I would lie in my bunk, hidden by the curtains & when he began to prattle on about the possibilities of striking a mine & other comforting things to expect I would draw Teddy’s attention & try & make him laugh. Chieffy Steward as Pinto called him would often allow his voice to get away & disturb me in my endeavour to sleep. I generally squirmed around a little & grunted & he would then keep quiet for a second until I snored. Then he would begin once more but before he had got a full head of piffle going I would yell out like fury & he would skedaddle out of the cabin

for his very life. His talk & the Chief Officer’s ideas were enough to drive anybody mad. The temperature today was 88deg in the cabin. During the afternoon a line of ships could be just discerned with the telescope away on the port bow. It was an Indian Convoy of twelve ships bound for Suez. That evening cool breezes sprang up & the barometer began to fall.
Entry.73:
At two am Teddy woke me with the news that we were "in it" once more. I wondered what he meant but as soon as I felt the rolling, I knew & felt quite happy over it – to Teddy’s disgust. He had a novel way of waking me. He would get into his pyjamas & then into his bunk & would lean out & whisper Hey! Hey! "You dopey son of a gun" & so forth. I generally waited until he leaned a little further over & would then make a sudden grab at him & would either land him on the floor or else frighten seven devils out of him. His one trouble was "SSh - - SSh - - you’ll wake the old man." One night I took half his bunk boards out & hid them, carefully spreading the mattress over the gap, expecting to see him go through into my bunk. He did too – legs in the air gentleman style - - but unfortunately I was too slow in getting out of my bunk with the consequence 

that he fell on top of me. As day broke the sea rose & the wind was a fairly stiff breeze. Teddy had been frequently waking owing to the monotonous tick – tick of a loose article somewhere that rolled about. Neither of us could find what it was & Teddy could not get to sleep owing to it. All day long the sea thumped into the A 13 & sent spray over her bridge. That evening I was in the bow of the A 13 getting the lovely cool air before retuning to roost when I saw long luminous snakes I thought, preceding the A 13, crossing & re-crossing one another in front of her forefoot. I watched them for a time & then went for Teddy but on my return they had gone – of course I was not sober according to the others but I was told that they were probably porpoise.
Entry.74:
far wireless messages had been very few & far between but at 3 am I heard Q.T.S calling a warship & knew that the Empress of Russia was not far away. At 7 am we passed the Twelve Apostle Islands which were shrouded in the misty haze although on Jebel Tiere – the largest of them could be seen the lighthouse of white stone away on its summit but as this belongs to Turkey it was in darkness. The islands are almost rocks & can hardly be termed islands. Half an hour later Q.T.S 

seemed to be very powerful so I walked out to have a look round. At the same time the engine room telegraph rang to stop as the Empress of Russia – an armed merchantman – signalled to heave to. A flag signal was then sent to the A 13 but owing to Captain Jackson ramping & swearing, the Chief Officer could not read it. Over went the code signal book & then the pencil as Captain Jackson roared out "What the ! ? ! does he say." At last the message was received – Keep fifty miles north of Sokotra owing to supposed enemy’s cruiser". That was the talk for some days after. Gradually the A 13 drew away as the Empress of Russia seemed to fade into the mist like a spectre that had emerged from practically nowhere, warned us & then disappeared again. The heavy sea was now hindering us & speed was down to 7½ knots.
Entry.75:
At 12.30 a.m. The A 13 passed through Hell’s Gates & passed Perim. At 10.30 a.m. preparations were being made to enter Aden. Chippy was brought to the fore again & rendered me an account of his life on the sea whilst waiting. What dreadful, barren, waste land it was as we drew into Aden in a smooth pale blue sea & a beautiful clear sky. Porpoise followed ahead & gambolled in the water as 

the A 13 almost ran them down – but not quite as a little speed extra & they were safe. Porpoise are most interesting fish to watch. They are often of enormous size & frequent warm waters in preference. They belong to the few fish who’s tails are parallel to the surface of the water. To watch them swim is fascinating as they can travel faster than any known fish & every few seconds they give a peculiar gasp as they jump clean out of the water & dive again. They do not seem to move their fins at all as they race along, under & over one another, but always too fast to be overtaken. They keep well to the surface as rule & can be easily seen, & although several dozen may be in a school, never do they collide with one another because of their quickness. As we drew near to the great cliffs & gaunt rocks that shield Aden, a little pilot boat put out to a steamer waiting to enter. The A 13 therefore stopped her engines & just glided along by her own momentum. The signal "Have you anything for me" was hoisted & the pilot answered "no", so after receiving further instructions from a miliary officer on board to keep 100 miles north of Sokotra we drew away from another of the fascinating lands of desert & rugged cliffs bound for Fremantle. 

The very possibilities of danger appealed to Teddy & I & although no doubt a very undesirable thought in itself. All lights were therefore shaded & Captain Jackson, the Chief Officer & the Chief Steward began to develop imaginations & spread weird tales, & naturally the "poor old operators" were called upon to "Keep a sharp watch"
Entry.76: At 1.30 a.m. A ship passed & signalled "Who are you" & "where to?" but the only reply was in edging well away from her. Dutch boats were very busy on their wireless stations & passed messages to one another from the Red Sea to towards Aden. Several pieces of war news were received & of course were fuel for all to talk over.
Entry.77: Still in dangerous waters & the divvel’s own day too. Hot & stifling with a sea like glass. At evening the course was altered towards Fremantle. H.M.A.T. Saldanha was still in sight & the Captain on that steamer kept pigeons & two of these escaped & flew to the A 13. A message was therefore sent to us to "catch ’em", but words are cheap & every time any attempt to catch them was made they shook their little tales & away they flew. Captain Jackson was all on for shooting them & making a pigeon pie.
Entry.78:
Yes! remarked Teddy in disgust. "In Wigan all the boys are out in the meadows playing football or else in the snow 

having a fight". "A life on the Ocean wave cooped up on this old tub compared to it" Eh! What? I remarked that I wanted to see London but he assured me that I would not be charmed by the appearance of London in winter. Slush, mud, rain & cold are the main sights to see. We then began to consider starting a Wireless Telegraphy School in Sydney & make 
tons
 of money etc. Anything to talk about. It gets very tiresome with nothing but old news to rake up. At breakfast for instance. Enter Captain Jackson & Chief Officer who sit in their places. Next comes the Chief Engineer & the same old question is again asked "What speed is she doing etc". Enter Teddy. "Anything during the night?" No! Sir! Enter his worship the author. "Any news during the morning?" "Yes sir! War news from Bombay H.M.T Thunderer torpedoed in the North Sea. Germans in Antwerp. Allies progressing favourably. Wouldn’t the Chief Officer bite. Pinto of course would immediately tell the Chief Steward & in a few moments the news was known all round – and Teddy & I would morse code "Liar" to each other by means of our feet. We dared not wink for fear of letting the cat out but how we laughed when alone. After breakfast there was a natural rush to our 

cabin for details - & how nicely we spun them. At night time our news was construed into fabulous tales of disaster & triumph. The next spasm of "War news" came when the last lot was worn out. How the Chief Steward would put his theory on our news & enlarge upon them. The Second officer always met us with "You horrible liars" – expressive if not polite, but he enjoyed the fun with us.
Entry.79:
& two days north of the Equator, with a heat enough to hatch eggs in a few hours. A special dinner was prepared for six p.m. & perhaps we all understood each other for lunch was very mild indeed. Six p.m. & with the stroke of the bell on the bridge we strolled into the saloon meeting the Chief Steward who waited for our testimony as to the table. Splendid. Spiffing etc. Decanters of wine with cards attached bearing the Compliments of the Season from Captain Jackson, Jellies & Ice Cream – a feast for the Gods. Everyone got to the end of the menu in time & some hung on to the last few dishes to "fill in time". Teddy & I came a good last & we waited for the Third Officer & kept him company. Without reflecting or finding fault we all noticed that the wine was by no means over proof but rather "wet" & was enough to send a milkman to gaol if he added as much 

water to his milk. The third officer finished at last – we were "de trop" – & we toddled out into the air. A meeting was then held in the Second Officer’s cabin & champagne & music were the leaders. Musical items were rendered up to midnight & by then throats were rather dry so they were wet again & the party disbanded & a confab was held in the Steward’s Cabin where the most glorious lies & abominable untruths were told. The Chief Engineer was debating on social questions & the "’ere ’eres" were jerked out in spasmodic grunts. He was just waving his finger, about to expound a great theory when I put my face up to the port hole & whether it was the contour of my dial or whether surprise on his part I know not but that theory froze in his throat & his eyes I thought would fall out of his head. I quickly withdrew & listened to him saying that he saw someone, something – – don’t know etc so I faded into bed.
Entry.80: Two a.m. there was someone at the rail wurr-r-r-pp: wurr-r-p & evidently in great distress. Chief Steward in his bunk dressed & with boots on. During the morning it was necessary to pack a gland in one of the cylinders which took about an hour
Entry.81:
I nipped a hammock from the hospital & had been 

trying to sleep in it but only succeeded in being turned out on the deck that had been painted with crude oil & my plight may better be imagined than explained. At 5.30 am the A 13 crossed the Equator. Flying fish are very numerous about here & southwards, some attaining very large size. They are somewhat like a very large dragon fly & skip along the surface of the water for considerable distances & then generally strike a wave & disappear. A strong light will attract them readily, & occasionally they are blown with great force against the ship which results in a mangled fish. In the afternoon the officers held a musical performance, outside the saloon door. All wore singlets & a pair of white trousers. Teddy as usual rendered his songs & the second steward – Jim – supplied the base to the music on my stringalina. He was very deaf & consequently ignorant of the discord emanating from the strings which he pulled as if plucking a duck.
Entry.82:
In the Doldrums again & fierce heat & damp moist air. Poor Teddy lay in his bunk with the perspiration rolling off him. I, myself had lately been parading the deck from 2 a.m. till 5 am in my pajamas with the coat undone. I was lovely & cool like this if any breeze was blowing, & made me feel quite happy at times but when the sun rose, it 

soon killed any high spirits. Tiddles the ship’s cat had yesterday given birth to a kitten which died & today she deliberately jumped overboard. After lunch I sorted out a few shirts & singlets that needed a wash & set about extracting the dirt. I soaked them first & then began to rub & scrub until the perspiration ran out of me. A little of this soon settled the question so I only washed the necks & cuffs & then hung up to dry. There being no irons to iron with, it was necessary to sleep on those clothes until they were as well as ironed. Washing had been done in Alexandria but all the buttons were either mangled off or else out of shape so it was now necessary to use wire & nails for buttons. No wireless messages had been received so far & not a scratch was to be heard in the phones, but after dinner today a faint but clear note could be heard from Bombay radio.
Entry.83:
At 4 a.m. the darkness was intense even the water being hidden & not a star was visible. The weather was getting slightly cooler but was still humid. At midnight every night a "sight" is taken to check the position of the ship. The officers know the stars as well as we know our own streets & at a glance will say "there is Orion" there are the Seven Sisters & so on. The Pole star was just out of sight now. 

This star is a very small one & is only visible north of the equator. It is only recognised by the two stars forming part of the Plough, which point to it thus:

(diagram of ‘The Plough’)
Entry.84: Early morning began with a heavy sea & thick drizzling rain & a dull leaden sky, which increased as the day wore on, making everything miserable. Teddy & I sat at the doorway & yarned about some fresh war news to spread around. "I knew it" said the Chief Officer who by the way always imagined he had heart disease & at the time was holding his side as if in agony. "Knew what?" said Captain Jackson coming on the scene. "That the Germans were about to invade England" he replied. "Dammit man where did you get that from" & an argument began that caused us great amusement. Of course the Chief Steward was in his glory & spread butter on the news.
Entry.85: The last day of 1914 was at hand & a nice day I don’t think. The sea was very heavy & the rain thicker
Entry.86:
Still raining & very heavy sea. I was feeling very sick & tired but had to keep going as to "be sick" simply meant throwing 

my shift on to Teddy.
Entry.87: Radio messages again in range – Perth working to Geraldton (W.A.) showing that we were nearing Australia.
Entry.88: Seas are still very heavy & everyone has a sore back through continually swaying to oppose the motion of rolling. The A 13 being hampered by adverse currents & winds should have been in Fremantle by now but still has 450 miles to go.
Entry.89:
A howling sea with gale of wind raging all night. Lying in my bunk it was a glorious feeling to rise up & up & then sink down again almost taking one’s breath away. By the light of the table lamp I could see Teddy dozing off so I got up & relieved him. He was feeling very sick so I got him some hot brandy & let him turn in. The A 13 was rolling like a barrel & the waves washing over her decks like over a submarine. The sea was running very high & a thick haze present owing to the presence of land. I had been watching the huge waves slowly but surely rolling towards us & several times I expected we would be swamped. The waves would tower above, a dark green colour & as they drew near, my heart would beat faster as I expected them to crash on us but there is a sensation of rising as the A 13 would climb this hill of water & as the wave passed under us there would be a 

delirious feeling of falling through space, that takes one’s breath away & feels like walking on air as the A 13 would dive down into the trough of the next one & would bury her nose in it & send a great green roller tearing over the decks. During this rolling I almost fell over the side as the A 13 took one beam on & swung over so sharply that I almost overbalanced. This same lurch brought the Captain out to see what was wrong & at the same time it turned Teddy out of his bunk & sent the crockery in the pantry all over the floor. I got the fright of my life through it & of course I was laughed at for not going over.
Entry.90:
At two a.m. Teddy awakened me & said that Fremantle was very close. I got dressed & went outside & there, away in the distance could be seen a revolving light on Rottennest Island – twelve miles from Fremantle. What a great work navigation is & how perfect it is. For just a month the A 13 had been steaming along, buffeted by gales & blown out of her course & yet she is heading for Fremantle as true & as straight as an arrow. No need to grope about the coast, nor even to alter the course. The way is like a beaten track to those who understand the sea. The moon was just half & the sky was clear & the water calm & everything seemed so peaceful. When five miles or so off Rottennest Island we got into communication 

with the lighthouse & received instructions by means of the morse lamp to proceed slowly towards Fremantle & a pilot would bring out sealed orders. At this time we were ignorant of the state of the war so we asked Rottennest Island Signal station for war news but as usual there was none. (Another work for us) At 5 am the pilot came out & came on board with sealed orders to proceed to Melbourne. After a little chat about the war news he wished us bon voyage & cast off. The Chief Steward then came blustering in with a paper he got off the pilot. He soon lost the run of it & Teddy & I handed it to the engineers – what was left of it. The sun rose with a blaze of crimson light over Australia & I must say I felt very impatient now to get to port. As we turned round to leave, HMAT Saldanha entered & we each dipped our ensigns on passing. That morning was the most glorious & peaceful I had ever seen. It was Sunday & the sea was a beautiful crystal blue, calm & clear & the land could be seen quite plainly. I spent the morning sitting in the sun up forrard & I must say it was a perfect day. At 4 pm the sea began to rise & the wind blew with increasing strength & once more the A 13 began to flounder in the sea.
Entry.91:
At two a.m. we were just "turning the corner" round Cape Lleuwin & the sea was a snorter. Every few seconds there was a 

sickening thud & the A 13 would bounce with the force of the blow. The men call these "milestones" & they put a great strain on a ship’s back. We were getting the force so heavily on account of our light trim. I went up forrard to my usual place clad in my pyjamas to see the most awe inspiring sight possible. The moon was quite bright & the sea was a mass of white crested waves that hurled themselves against the A 13 with a vicious thud & were sent back again in a shower of spray like fine snow. The wind too was moaning a shrieking & was so strong that I was afraid that I should either be blown overboard or else have my pyjamas blown away so I got hold of the ironwork. It was a magnificent spectacle from where I was, as I could see all over the ship as she plodded along throwing the waves back like froth. Shipwreck – what an awful word & how it struck home at the time. On land we do not realise the awfulness of shipwreck & what could a boat do in a sea like this. The very thought of shipwreck was enough to chill one’s heart. Teddy always remarked in rough weather that in England all the parish churches pray for "Those in peril on the sea" in stormy weather & there is always a prayer for those in the North Sea exposed to danger. How often do our Australian churches think of those away from their 

immediate vicinity. Plenty of time for arguing about No License & other debates but very seldom do we hear a prayer for those at sea. I often wondered if the people at home ever thought of the dangers 
at sea
 to their soldiers – not from bullets so much but while on the sea. In Australia he (Teddy) said if it rains or a squall rises, every body makes for home & never gives a thought to the man behind the gun as it were. It is the same everywhere. How often do we think of the engine driver who has our lives in his hands as he tears through the country. Very seldom – he is paid for it . . . quite so. At sea everybody respects the Captain & the officers under him for it is upon their command & judgment that our lives depend, & yet, what a helpless band we are, each in his own sphere. Captain – responsible for all. Officers answerable to him – Operators ready to send out a call for help. Three letters only & what a meaning it has. S.O.S. Simply three dots, three dashes, & three dots & when heard every other message, no matter how important, whether Government or Public message must stop & the S.O.S. call must be answered. Should the operator name any particular station in reference to a distress call, then that station is responsible for the assistance to be rendered. Any abuse of this call 

is liable to bring most severe punishment. And what a great institution this Wireless telegraphy is. Isolated from the world & perhaps on fire a ship calls CQ (all stations) S.O.S from (ship’s call letters) & every ship that hears that call is bound to render assistance – not a case of excuse for not going – but is actually forced by act to go to the distressed one. Land wireless stations hearing a distress call from a ship immediately use their full power & call QRT which commands all stations to stop transmitting immediately. There is no "wait a minute" The words are precise & final. From the charts in the land station the position of all boats within range is known & from this land station all orders are issued & no matter how important a message may be it has to wait as no station dare to transmit until the distressed one is relieved & the controlling station calls CQ . . . OK. Not speaking for myself at all I would like to draw attention to the patience & perseverance of an operator. He is generally looked upon as a gay young fellow at an easy game, but what is behind the position? A great deal more than we suppose at first thought. He is often taxed to his utmost to overcome atmospherical conditions & the resulting phenomena & a most intricate machine to handle – not a toy but a scientifically constructed machine that is capable of great results if handled well but in an 

inexperienced hand it is a very dangerous machine. People say "Why it is simply tapping at a key" "Quite so but that "tapping" takes years to learn & there is far more than a mere tapping to do. There is a maze of wires each with a purpose & the operator must be familiar with them all. After the little I saw of Operating I am convinced that it is a noble but sadly underpaid profession for when his actual self stands forth he is the second last to leave a ship in distress & only then when he can do no more. All honour to those at sea, for they fear nothing. A year at sea would make more of a man than several on land.
Entry.92: Sea again down to smooth. Potatoes off the Menu owing to the supply giving out. A new dish was made Bully beef rissoles & my snakes talk about salt & leather – Even Captain Jackson would not look at them & worse than that they were tainted. Teddy painted the cabin with white enamel & made an awful smell of turps. No sleep that night & on
Entry.93: Teddy & I were both about "done" & longed for Melbourne. We each buoyed the other up with such remarks as "Never mind Melbourne is near."
Entry.94: Very cold & need for three blankets each, but sleep comes with it what little can be got. S.S. Demosthenes en route to England sends short war news at 8 pm.
Entry.95: Washing clothes early in the morning. Pass a four masted barque bound for Adelaide. That night Adelaide (VIA) called H.M.A.T. Saldanha but could not get an answer for some time. The sea was very calm & peaceful & at eleven pm. Mount Gambia Radio (VIY) South Australia came into range.
Entry.96:
The sun rose in a splendour of golden light & over a peaceful sea. Decks were hosed & cleaned ready to make port. At 6 am I reported that Melbourne Radio was in range & a message was sent to the Naval Authorities advising our arrival at midnight. Great trouble was experienced in getting this message through. At about ten o’clock (a.m.) we steamed through an enormous shoal of porpoise some thousands in number. At 2 pm a dense fog came down like a blanket & then the trouble began. Every 45 seconds or so the whistle would almost deafen us as it sent out the warning. A fog tends to stop sound & at a short distance our whistle would have been inaudible. There was no sleep that morning & I felt absolutely physically & mentally tired out. We could not find our bearings to enter Port Philip so steamed along at a very slow rate. At this time if anyone makes a noise he will surely be jumped upon by the Captain as all ears are strained for the approach of another vessel. The fog lifted later on & we put on full speed. On passing the rip, searchlights played 

upon us until we hoisted the pass signal. A pilot then took us up to Port Melbourne & anchored at just on three am
Entry.97: I did not wait for anyone but earthed the instruments & closed them down & jumped into bed clothes & all. Muster was the next I remembered & we then steamed into the pier. As most people know Melbourne I shall not remark upon it.
Entry.98: At 5 pm I left Melbourne by train for Sydney after bidding farewell to all on board, which I admit I did not like doing. Teddy came down to the train & as we parted I felt that I had lost a great friend for he had been very kind to me. He is still away at the Dardanelles & if ever I get the chance of doing him a service I shall be there.
